Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for participation in the Representations of Riemannian Geometry Conference, to be held August 10-13, 2017 at Saint Joseph's University in Philadelphia, PA. The conference focuses on modern developments in global Riemannian geometry and the relationship between global metric geometry and topology. In the recent past these fields were very important in several breakthroughs in mathematics. For example, methods from both geometric analysis and metric geometry were crucial for the proof of the famous Poincaré conjecture, which goes back to the year 1900 and is the only one of the Millennium Prize problems to be solved to date. These areas of mathematics also have many applications, for example to physics, chemistry, engineering, and big data analysis. This funding will help to involve early-career mathematicians, including graduate students and postdocs. Special attention will be devoted to identifying and supporting women and other members of underrepresented groups. There will be speaking opportunities for junior researchers and graduate students, as well as a full day of introductory talks with the goal of attracting a broader audience. The conference will include speakers and participants who work in several research areas, thus further encouraging cross-collaborations.

The conference will feature eleven plenary speakers with plenty of time between talks to encourage discussion and the interchange of ideas. Additionally, there will be three talks given by graduate students. The technical areas represented by the conference include several areas of global Riemannian geometry: symmetries of spaces with lower curvature bounds, special Riemannian metrics (especially Einstein metrics, Kähler metrics, and warped products), families of harmonic self-maps of spheres, foliations of spheres, projective and conformal geometry, homogeneous Ricci flow and isometric flow on orbit spaces, isoparametric hypersurfaces, path spaces, and closed geodesics. The overlap between these areas makes very real the possibility for cross-collaboration among the participants, and the conference activities will bring together leading experts and young researchers and students, facilitating the dissemination of recent research progress and discussion of future directions and open problems.

The conference webpage is available at: http://palmer.wellesley.edu/~geom-conf/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report:

 The award supported the mathematics conference “Representations of Riemannian Geometry”, which was held at Saint Joseph’s University in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. This international conference involved 59 participants from around the United States and four foreign countries. The conference began on Thursday, Aug. 10, 2017 and ended on Sunday, Aug. 13, 2017. There were ten plenary talks and four slightly shorter talks by early career mathematicians and graduate students.  Between talks there was ample time for mathematical discussions and exchange of ideas.  The conference met its goal of having at least half of the speakers be female (8/14), which is a departure from many mathematics conferences in which women are underrepresented among speakers. The award provided support to participants, including lodging and full or partial travel support. No honoraria or other compensation was paid from the award.  About 50% of the travel and lodging support was awarded to early career researchers consisting of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.

 The subject of the conference was Riemannian Geometry, which is a branch of differential geometry. This area of mathematics involves the study of shapes in many dimensions. It is important in its own right but also has connections to many other areas of mathematics, including analysis, topology, partial differential equations, algebra and algebraic geometry as well as applications to physics, image processing, data science, robotics, chemistry and biological sciences.  The website for the conference is http://palmer.wellesley.edu/~geom-conf/ where titles and abstracts can be found. The conference also received support for refreshments and other expenses from the departments of mathematics at Saint Joseph’s University, Oregon State University, the University of Pennsylvania and the University of Muenster, Germany.   

Intellectual Merit: Riemannian geometry is an area of mathematics that is highly active and has applications to many fields, including some outside of mathematics.  Conference participants represented major universities from across the United States and from several foreign countries. The conference featured fourteen speakers in diverse branches of differential geometry, and participants had ample time for additional discussions.

Broader Impacts: Diversity was an important factor to the organizers of the conference. More than half of the speakers were women, a group underrepresented in mathematics and (even more severely) as speakers at major mathematics conferences. The conference also provided full financial support to early career researchers, who traditionally have fewer resources for travel than established mathematicians.
